bibl.title: Letter from [Juan Guiteras] to William Crawford Gorgas, December 22, 1916

div1.p: [Guiteras] reports to Gorgas on a Barbados epidemic, which he suspects may be yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Juan Guiteras] to William Crawford Gorgas, December 22, 1916
div1.opener:
Port of Spain. December 22, 1916.
Gral. W. C. Gorgas, Chairman
Rockefeller Yellow Fever Commission.
Dear Doctor:-
div1.p:
My experience in Barbados has been rather trying, be-
cause of the difficulties inherent to the problem itself, and
the responsibilities attached. A form of febrile jaundice with
albuminuria affecting a large number of people in one of the
West India islands is very suspicious of yellow fever. I was
never before confronted with such a situation; but I may say
that I have been helped by all concerned.

I am sending you a number of temperature charts, co-
pies of which I am keeping in my note book. If I have time here
I shall transfer them first to uniform charts, I think these charts
should be published with such notes as I have of each case.

I am sending you also copy of a newspaper report of a
lecture I deleivered here and of my letter to the Barbados autho-
rities.

As we had expressed it in our conversations, the fact
that all the persons attacked were negroes was a strong point
against yellow fever. Even the case you saw autopsied was not
a pure white, as I found out later. Excepting him and one mild
case, also nearly white, the few who were not blacks were dark
mulattos.

It was a disease of the blacks and of the poorer class
of blacks.

There were 10 deaths, and they were all blacks with the
exception of the one you saw.

The findings in the autopsies was the first bases they
had for the diagnosis of yellow fever, and, if we consider only
the naked eye appearances, such findings were perhaps the most
suspicious feature of all.

I saw one other autopsy, the features being the same
that you observed, a very dark liver and extremely congested,
2.
the blood welling up profusely on cutting into the organ. Four
of the 10 livers were found in this condition, and one doubtful
as it was desenbed “pale but not bowwood” the other five were de-de-
senbedscribed as boxwood.

The stomach contained four times black vomit, once a dark
gray fluid containing blood, and no black vomit in the other five.

In the case with the dark gray fluid, which I saw, the
mucosa of the stomach was pale. It appears to have presented pete-
chiœ in other cases.

The causes with black vomit in the stomach had dark li-
vers, the others had pale livers only one case presented at the same
time black fluid in the stomach with boxwood liver.
The spleen was enlarged in one case.
Some nephritis is desenbeddescribed in all.

The bodies were all of a very deep yellow color, show-
ing under the black and very intense in the selerotics.

The histelogricalgical findings are strongly against yellow
fever, the liver cells are rarely foatty even in the livers that
were desenbeddescribed as boxwood in some of the autopsies. The necrotic
areas of liver cells are generally absent. In one case occasionally
such are seen, quite irregularly distributed. The blood capillaries
are distributeddistended, and some times very decidedly so.

The short fatal case of 5 days durations deserves special
consideration, Joseph Miller, black, aged 23 years, had been work-
ing in a water trench, and is admitted on December 7th with a his-
tory of onset of the disease on the 4th with a chill, vomiting and
pain in the loins. He is the only one of the cases I have seen
who points distinctly to such pain. The patients thinks that on
the third day he vomited once a fluid that contained blood. He
staggers on admission and is quite weak, but his mind perfectly
clear. He has jaundice and albumin that begins to precipitate soon
after the examination. At 4 pm. the Temp. is 99-5° and Pulse 76. On
the 8th in the morning Temp. 98-4° and Pulse 88. In the evening Temp.
101° and Pulse 100. He died the following morning early
3.
dyspriœa
after a sudden attack of dypriœa. No convulsions. He had been
pasing urina freely and there had been but a slight increase of
the albumin on the 8th. jaundice quite intense.

The autposy shows a dark and greatly congested liver
Upon section the blood wells up rapidly fillyfilling the gap. The sto-
mach contains about a pint of dark gray fluid which contains some
blood. The mucous membrane is swollen and pale without echymotic
spots. The spleen is much congested. The left lung is very much
engorged and semisplenified. The upper right lobe is less so,
but the lower right lobe is blanched and completely collapsed.
Probably some sudden obstruction of the bronchus (which was not
looked for) was the cause of the death, and may explain the short
duration of the disease which appeared to be tending towards re-
covery.
Chemical features:

The duration of the cases was too long. My record of cases
in the past shows that the majority of deaths in yellow fever
occur on the 6th. day of the disease.

The duration in these 10 fatal cases was:
1 died on the 5th day.
1 " " " 6th "
3 " " " 7th "
1 " " " 8th "
1 " " " 10th "

Which gives us an average duration of 8.6 days. The ave-
rage duration of the Guayaquil, Panamá, (Buena Ventura) and
Trinidad fatal cases, the only histories at my desposal here was
6.4 days.

The duration of the cases terminatinf in recovery was
likewise too long. In the majority of cases in Havana the dura-
tion was of 7 days. Comparing the Barbados cases with those of
Guayaquil, Buena Ventura and Trinidad we find the following ave-
rages of duration.
For the Barbadas cases 13.6 days.
For the Guayaquil, Buena Ventura and Trinidad 7.4 days.

Studing the charts we observe a tendency to a typhoid type
with the occasional occurrence of a secondary rise disenbed in
Weyl's disease, and as I have observed in the sporadice cases
in Havana.
will

The temperature charts, you weel observe are generally
quite distinct from yellow fever.

Please note the one of Constance Coppin which was the
last case reported positively soon after my arrival. There are
7 days in succession in which the temperature rises to 104 or
over. Now no case of yellow fever ever got that far under such
circumstances, nor recovered. This one recovers, the temperature
having reached the normal 4 or 5 days after the last recorded
in the chart I am sending you.

With the regard to the pulse though we notice often
a slow pulse, is is found generally rather late, as a consequence
of the jaundice; so that we do not see the timetrue Faget sign of the
diverging lines of the temperature and pulse. It is timetrue that
the cases generally came in too late under observation, but this
in itself is an indication against yellow fever.

The jaundice in these cases has been more intense than
that of yellow fever; has appeared later, and when it has appear-
ed it has devolped very rapidly. Even in light cases the jaun-
dice has been very well marked and the urine has contained lar-
ge amounts of bile pigment. In others words, we have had, I think
very distinctly the evidences of an obstructureive jaundice. To
my knowledge the stools have been white in four of the cases.

ItAs is a matter of fact, until the two deaths occurred
on the 22nd of September, it was generally believed by our con-
freres that they had been having an epidemic of jaundice all over
the island without anything extraordinary about the cases, except
their frequency and the tendency of some of them to be prolongued
and “to turn into typhoid” as one of the physicians expressed it.

Vomiting was absent in a considerable number of cases,
perhaps about one half. In some it was quite persistent. But
I believe there was no one with characteristic black vomit. One
vomit, or perhaps more than once, containing blood, is now and
then mentioned, but never the persistent and proyectile vomiting
of black liquid that is met with in the fatal and grave cases
of yellow fever.

The liver and spleen were somewhat enlarged in some
cases, and the former organ was quite tender, more often than
the epigastrium in the cases that I saw. We should not forget
in this connexion that there is no malaria in Barbadas.

Albumin. There are no exact data in most cases, as
to the date of commencement of the albuminuria. As I have said
with reference to the jaundice, the cases came rather late under
observation, and even so the albumin appeared sometimes after
admission. I beleive that this symptom appeared generally la-
ter than in yellow fever. It certainly cannot be shown that it
appeared on the third day in the majority of instances. In the
cases in which I tested for albumin the amount was less than
what is found in yellow fever in corresponding conditions of gra-
vity. I gather that this was also true in examinations made by
others, though some of my friends, I beleive, will not agree
with me. The sring test was frequently employed and I was told
that albumin was shown by it and at times not by the heat and
acid test. I beleive that the layer test may give merise to confu-
sion in concentrated muddy and bilious urine, if the latter is
not cleared by filtration.

The absence of restlessness and of complaint of spon-
taneous pains in the back, the head and limbs was a feature of
the cases that I saw. You would have to ask direct questions
to get any history of spontaneous pains and they were generally
of the head. On the other hand I did not find the tenderness
of the muscles that I have observed in sporadic Weyl's disease.

The mental condition of the patients was not such as
we meet in yellow fever. The patients were quiet dull, somewhat
6.
depressed, I saw no one with excitement, or reasioning and talk-
ative delirium.

In the short time at my desposal it was not possible
to record and present the cases in a systematic form. I simply
observed symptoms and facts from day to day, and weighed them
with a view to arriving at a diagnosis of the epidemic.

I have recorded 46 cases concerning some of which I
have but few data, at times only the temperature, and occasionally
only the name given as of an individual belonging to this group
of cases.

Out of 46 cases, 10 died. This gives a case mortality
of 21.7%. I am sure, however that a very large number of light
cases, and even those of a severer type that occurred early in
the epidemic, are left out of this calculation. I amd inclined
to think that the case-mortality did not exceed 4 or 6%.

Of the 46 cases that were reported or were the subject
of some study from the view point of yellow fever, less than one
third, I beleive, were officially reported as suffering from
that disease. Of the 46 cases I saw certainly 22, and perhaps
a few others that were convadescing. I saw also two post mortoms
and examined the organs microspically in five of the fatal cases
from preparations made by the Pathogutlogist of the Central Board of
Health, Dr. Johnson, who kindly assisted me in all my investi-
gations.

The cases were distributed rather irregularly over
many of the parrishes. The port town, Bridgetown, was singularly
exempt at the beginning of the outbreak.

The first case reported as yellow fever occurred in
St. Andrews, the least accessible of all the parrishes, the second
case in St. Georges, the third also in St. George, without any
connexion between the two, the fourth in St. Michaels, the fifth
in St. James, and likewise the sixth. Some of the cases of jaun-
dice, however, did procede from the same neighborhood, but very
rarely from the same house. Of the 10 deaths, seven proceded
each one from a distinct parrish. Three parrishes, St. Andrews,
7.
St. James and St. Mchaels had each 2 deaths.

The cases reported as yellow fever in what is called
the first outbreak in September are the following:
1 --Thomas Foster ------Black--Barbadian --Aged 60 years.
2 --Joseph Smith -------" --" --" 41 "
3 --Arnold Clarke ------" --" --" 12 "
4 --Gertrude Inniss ----" --" --" 31 "
5 --Joseph Small -------" --" --" 50 "
6 --James Walcott ------" --" --" 50 "

Of these six cases, four were living at the time of
the great epidemic of 1881, and all were living at the time of
the epidemic of 1908.

Such individuals generally escape in and epidemic of
yellow fever, having been immunized by a previous attack. It
certainly is highly unprobable that such individuals, all of them
blacks, and all residents of the country distinctstricts in the interior,
could be singled out to constitute the first cases of a new out-
break.

Complete records of previous epidemics of yellow fever
in Barbadas are not available. We should bear in mind that the
colored population is greatly in excess over the white in that
Island, and that cases of yellow fever among the former should
be comparatively frequent. But I have seen epidemics of the di-
sease in communities where there was a very large colored popu-
lation, and though many of them may have had yellow fever, we
never became cogrisant of the fact, because the disease was very
mild among them, and the deaths were extremely rare, especially
among the pure blacks. Witness the epidemics of Jacksonville
(1888) and Brunswick (1893) where many years had ellapsed since
the last previous epidemic, and where there was therefore, a very
large non-immune population of white and colored.

Let us look into such records as we have of the two
last epidemics of Barbadas.

There is no registation of deaths in that Island, so we
know nothing of the intervening years, and very little of the
epidemic years.

We know that the garrison was seriously affected in
1881 and that the troops had to be removed.

There is a very interesting tabulated presentation of
the cases treated that year in one yellow fever hospital by Dr.
St. Claire Browne. He had under his care 36 patients in which
the diagnosis of the disease was confirmed. Of these, 11 were
whites, 7 colored and 18 blacks. The fatal cases were 4, and
they were all whites. There was besides, one fatal case of
pneumonia, who is supposed, on in sufficient grounds, I beleive,
to have had also yellow fever. He was a black man who had a per-
sistent high temperatre, with slight albuminuria. Jaundice appear-
ed on the 10th day of the disease, and he died of gangrene of the
lungs.

Of the fatal cases, one died on the 6th. day, one on
the 7th, one on the 9th and one on the 22nd day. The latter is
a very doubtful case. The post mortom findings are Liver “much
enlarged, pale and hard, but congested”, spleen much enlarged,
stomach “healthy and empty”.

We mustnext hear of yellow fever in an epidemic form in Decem-
ber of 1908. The official records as far as they go, give a re-
sumé of 86 cases with 20 deaths, but it is generally understood
that the disease was much more widely prevalent than these figu-
res would indicate.

div1.p:
The incidence of yellow fever was decidedly greater in
the white race, and the death rate was greater still.

The difference may be expressed in the following formula:
The relation of colored to whites, in reference to the
number of cases, is as 1:5.15.
The relation of colored to whites in reference to the
number of deaths, is as 1:10.62.

Epidemic jaundice, febrile jaundice, infectious jaun-
dice appears to have been more prevalent in recent years than
formerly. Grissinger's bilious typhoid is disenbeddescribed in recent mo-
nographs on the diseases of Egypt. There has been an extensive
epidemic in the Italian army of accupation in Tripoli; another
epidemic in the army fighting in the Gallipoli peninsula. It
appears to have been demonstrated that this outbreak was due to
a paratyphoid infection. More recently an epidemic in Japan has
been shown to be a form of spirochetosis, and this appears to
have been confirmed in connexion with a very recent outbreak
among the troops in Flanders.

Conditions somewhat similar to these prevailing in the
armies mentioned may be said to exist, to some extent, at the
present time in Barbadas. This island is one of the most densely
populated countries in the world, the late season has been cha-
racterised by the heaviest and most persistent rains in many
years, the rise in the price of food stuffs renders it probable
that the articles of this kind for the consumption of the poor,
10.
have been of bad quality.

In mentioning these three conditions I am touching upon
factors that may, with some show of reason, be suggested as possi-
ble causes of the disease. Forms of food poisoning or food infec-
tion have been frequently suggested, and our own experience in
Havana with sporadic cases of grave febrile jaundice, point to
the probability of infection through the skin by prolonged im-
mersion of the feet in more or less poluted water.

The last heavy rain of the season occurred in Barbadas
during the first days of December. I remained there only eleven
days which were very dry, and my impression was that the epi-
demic was declining rapidly. This however requires confirmation.
The epidemic of yellow fever of 19018-09, on the other hand began
on the 12 of December and terminated in the following June.

I regret very much that the absence of all records of
deaths in Barbadas has made it impossible for me to apply, for
the epidemiologic disgnosis, the test obtained by study of the
death rate of children and of certain diseases, as I have done
in other places visited by the Commission.
div1.closer:
Yours very truly Member of the Rockefeller
Yellow Fever Commission.
